docs.lead_paragraph: STERNFELD--Leon, MD, PhD, MPH, died at his home in Oakland, CA., on Monday, November 24. Born in Brooklyn, NY on June 15, 1913 to Jewish immigrant parents, Leon spent his earliest years in a Labor Zionist agricultural community in Clarion, Utah. After the outbreak of World War I, with economic opportunities opening up in the big cities, Leon and his parents moved to Chicago, IL, where he grew up. He attended college and medical school at the University of Chicago, where he also earned a doctoral degree in biochemistry. As a teenager in Chicago, he met his future wife, Ruth Schwartz, to whom he was married for 73 years, and with whom he raised two daughters, Kay and Barbara. After completing an internship in pediatrics and communicable diseases at Johns Hopkins and a residency in pediatrics at Brooklyn Jewish Hospital, Leon took a Public Health Traineeship with the New York State Department of Health; during that time, he completed a Masters of Public Health in Maternal and Child Health at Columbia University. He then worked as Director of the Bureau of Medical Rehabilitation in the NY State Department of Health until 1950 when he took a position as Assistant Director, Tuberculosis Control, in the Massachusetts Department of Public Health. After a tour of active duty as Chief of the Public Health Administration in South Korea, Leon returned to Massachusetts, serving first as Commissioner of Health in Cambridge and then as Deputy Commissioner in the state Department of Public Health. In 1970, Leon and Ruth moved to New York City where he served as the Medical Director of the United Cerebral Palsy Association and United Cerebral Palsy Research and Educational Foundation until he retired in 1993. In 1991, he was recognized by the American Academy for Cerebral Palsy and Developmental Medicine with a Distinguished Service Award, and in 1998, he was honored with the Research and Public Health Leadership award from Life Services for the Handicapped. Leon was the patriarch and anchor for the extended Sternfeld clan, full of wisdom and practical advice and always ready with his infectiously positive attitude, quick wit, humor and contagious laugh. He is survived by his daughter, Barbara, of Kensington, CA, his brother-in-law, Leo Sreebny of Seattle, WA, his son-in-law, Virgil Vickers of Newton, MA, his granddaughter, Rani Vickers Dalton, and great-granddaughter, Kayley Dalton, of Waltham, MA, as well as his step-grandson and family, Michael and JoLynn Carroll and their children, Julia and Phillip, of Tromso, Norway, and many loving nieces and nephews. He was predeceased by his wife, Ruth, and daughter, Kay. Donations in his memory may be sent to the American Museum of Natural History in New York or the United Cerebral Palsy Associations. 1/3

docs.lead_paragraph: 75 years ago, Marguerite Perey unearthed an element on the periodic table while working as a technician in Marie Curie’s lab. Her achievement came at a great cost.

headline.main: My Great-Great-Aunt Discovered Francium. And It Killed Her.

docs.abstract: Veronique Greenwood article recounts experience of her great-great-aunt Marguerite Perey, who worked under Marie Curie, and came to discover element francium at great cost to her health because of radiation poisoning; says story is a reminder that society should celebrate scientists for their courage and tenacity required to discover anything at all.
docs.snippet: 75 years ago, Marguerite Perey unearthed an element on the periodic table while working as a technician in Marie Curie’s lab. Her achievement came at a great cost.

docs.lead_paragraph: A Cuban doctor who contracted Ebola in Sierra Leone and was cured after experimental treatment in a Swiss hospital vowed on Saturday to return to West Africa and continue treating patients.

headline.main: At Home and Cured of Ebola, Cuban Doctor Vows Return to Africa
headline.print_headline: At Home and Cured of Ebola, Cuban Doctor Vows Return to Africa

docs.snippet: A Cuban doctor who contracted Ebola in Sierra Leone and was cured after experimental treatment in a Swiss hospital vowed on Saturday to return to West Africa and continue treating patients.

headline.main: Think Like a Doctor: A Hideous Sore

docs.abstract: Solve a real-life medical mystery: A young doctor develops a repulsive rash on her arm. Then her boyfriend gets it, too.
docs.snippet: Solve a real-life medical mystery: A young doctor develops a repulsive rash on her arm. Then her boyfriend gets it, too.

docs.lead_paragraph: GlaxoSmithKline is to shed hundreds of U.S. commercial and research jobs, restructuring operations in its biggest market where drug sales are flagging.

headline.main: GSK Cuts U.S. Research and Sales Jobs as Market Gets Tougher
headline.print_headline: GSK Cuts U.S. Research and Sales Jobs as Market Gets Tougher

docs.snippet: GlaxoSmithKline is to shed hundreds of U.S. commercial and research jobs, restructuring operations in its biggest market where drug sales are flagging.

docs.lead_paragraph: GlaxoSmithKline said on Wednesday it would shed "several hundred" U.S. commercial jobs and a similar number of research positions as it restructures operations in its biggest market, where drug sales are flagging.

headline.main: GSK Cuts U.S. Sales and Research Jobs as Market Gets Tougher
headline.print_headline: GSK Cuts U.S. Sales and Research Jobs as Market Gets Tougher

docs.snippet: GlaxoSmithKline said on Wednesday it would shed "several hundred" U.S. commercial jobs and a similar number of research positions as it restructures operations in its biggest market, where drug sales are flagging.

docs.lead_paragraph: Early editions of the Access to Medicine Index focused on infectious and tropical diseases, but the list has been refined to include access to drugs to mental illnesses.

headline.main: GlaxoSmithKline Leads In Getting Drugs to Poor
headline.print_headline: GlaxoSmithKline Leads in Getting Drugs to Poor

docs.abstract: Access to Medicine Index reports that, for fourth time, GlaxoSmithKline tops its list ranking pharmaceutical companies by how effectively they help the world’s poor get needed medicines.
docs.snippet: Early editions of the Access to Medicine Index focused on infectious and tropical diseases, but the list has been refined to include access to drugs to mental illnesses.

docs.abstract: How can the development and testing of Ebola drugs and vaccines help fight the outbreak while respecting ethical standards?
docs.snippet: How can the development and testing of Ebola drugs and vaccines help fight the outbreak while respecting ethical standards?
